title: 103_s224
content: The "Enhanced Rescissions Act of 1993" allows for expedited consideration of certain proposed rescissions under the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974. The "Enhanced Rescissions Act of 1993" permits the President to propose rescinding budget authority from an appropriations Act within 3 days of enactment, with a draft bill or resolution included for each item of authority to be rescinded. The "Enhanced Rescissions Act of 1993" allows the President to propose rescinding budget authority within 3 days of enactment, including a draft bill or joint resolution for each item to be rescinded. Special messages must specify the budget authority to be rescinded and follow expedited consideration procedures in Congress. The "Enhanced Rescissions Act of 1993" allows the President to propose rescinding budget authority within 3 days of enactment. The draft bill or joint resolution accompanying the special message must be introduced by the originating House. If not introduced, any Member of that House may introduce it after the third day of continuous session. The bill or joint resolution shall be referred to the Committee on Appropriations without substantive revision and reported within seven days. The "Enhanced Rescissions Act of 1993" allows the President to propose rescinding budget authority within 3 days of enactment. If the Committee on Appropriations fails to report the bill within the specified period, they will be automatically discharged, and the bill will be placed on the calendar for consideration. A vote on final passage must be taken within 10 days of the bill's introduction, with the Clerk of the House of Representatives or the Secretary of the Senate handling the process. The bill or joint resolution agreed to in the House or Senate must be engrossed, certified, and transmitted to the other House on the same day. It will then be referred to the Committee on Appropriations without substantive revision, and the committee must report it within seven days of receiving the bill. The bill or joint resolution must be reported by the Committee on Appropriations within seven days of receiving it. If the committee fails to do so, they will be automatically discharged, and the bill will be placed on the calendar for consideration. A vote on final passage must be taken within 10 days of the bill being transmitted to the House. The engrossed bill or joint resolution must be returned to the originating House by the Clerk of the House (in the case of the House of Representatives) or the Secretary of the Senate (in the case of the Senate). A motion to proceed to consider a bill or joint resolution under this section in the House of Representatives is highly privileged and not debatable. Debate on a bill or joint resolution under this section in the House of Representatives is limited to 4 hours, divided equally between those in favor and those opposed. Consideration of a bill or joint resolution under this section shall not exceed 4 hours, divided equally between supporters and opponents. Limiting debate further is not allowed, and appeals on procedural decisions shall be decided without debate. Consideration of a bill or joint resolution under this section in the Senate is governed by specific rules. A motion to proceed is privileged and not debatable, with a limited 10-hour debate time divided between majority and minority leaders. Amendments to the motion are not allowed, and reconsideration of the vote is prohibited. Debate in the Senate on any debatable motion or appeal in connection with a bill or joint resolution under this section shall be limited to 1 hour, divided between the mover and the manager of the bill, with additional time allotted by the leaders if needed. On the passage of a bill or joint resolution, additional time can be allotted to any Senator during the consideration of a debatable motion or appeal. Amendments are prohibited, and no motion to further limit debate or recommit a bill is allowed. Any amount of budget authority proposed to be rescinded must be made available for obligation. Any amount of budget authority proposed to be rescinded in a special message transmitted to Congress shall be made available for obligation on the day after the date on which either House defeats the bill or joint resolution transmitted with that special message. Definitions for terms like 'appropriation Act' and 'continuity of a session of Congress' are provided for clarity. The adjournment of more than 3 days to a day certain is excluded in the computation of continuous session periods. If a special message is transmitted during a Congress and the last session adjourns before 10 days of continuous session, the message is deemed transmitted on the first day of the next Congress. Section 904 of the Act is amended to include sections 1013 and 1018. Section 1011 is also amended to replace references to 1013 with 1014, and references to 1016 and 1017 with 1017 and 1018 respectively. Section 1015 is amended to replace references to 1012 or 1013. Section 1015 of the Act is amended to replace references to 1012 or 1013 with 1012, 1013, or 1014. Subsection (b)(1) is amended to replace references to 1012 with 1012 or 1013, and subsection (b)(2) is amended to replace references to 1013 with 1014. Subsection (e)(2) is also amended to replace references to 1013 with 1014. Section 1016 of the Act is amended to include references to section 1014. The table of sections is also updated to reflect these changes. "Section 1013: Expedited consideration of certain proposed rescissions."
